Morality is a lie. It is something that has been created by humans and pertains only to us as humans. Our natural instinct for survival is reflected with the survival of the woman. We see it as a good thing because we are human and seeing human life preserved is registered as good. In the grand scheme of things, it doesn't matter. The woman's survival wouldn't have mattered. She could die or not die and it wouldn't matter. Life would go on without her. Those close to her would grieve at her loss, but it wouldn't matter. We are programmed to view human life and emotions as things that matter, but they only matter relative to us as humans. The world has no emotions other than those that we project onto it because we are human. We perceive things with emotion; that's part of what makes us human. Set aside human emotions and you'll see that the world is blank. There is no good or evil, as those are things that are relative to us and our emotions. Human emotions lie upon the foundations for morality. We perceive things as good or bad based upon our emotions. The world around us has no emotions. Our emotions carry weight only to us as people, not to the reality that we exist in.

I think one of the obfuscating problems with capital punishment is how much human societies suck at it.

In the United States, our justice system yields a lot of false convictions. Inmates on death row are routinely exonerated after the fact, and that's limited to those who are privileged to have an exoneration team continuing to investigate their case (not all of them do).

And then there's the matter that we can't seem to find a consistently humane way of killing someone. Our current methods, including lethal injection, hanging, gas chamber, firing squad and electric chair are far from painless or distressing to the convict being killed (let alone executioners, technicians, officers and witnesses).

And then there's those executions that are committed ad hoc, the about-one-thousand-per-year fatal officer-involved slayings (mostly shootings) by officers of law enforcement, which occur without due process and routinely with insufficient review or oversight.

Before we can even discuss the morality of capital punishment, we'd have to assure that it is conducted humanely and is painless to the convict, that wrongful convictions are so rare the risk of killing an innocent person is negligible (say, one per century), and that the sentence of capital punishment is issued only in the most heinous of crimes after all other possibilities are ruled out.

Until then, capital punishment puts the responsibility of innocent and cruel deaths on the state and its people, which is an unconscionable situation.

The burglar did a good thing, but he doesn't deserve praise because he set out to do a bad thing and had no intention of doing the good thing that he did.

When someone does a good thing for a bad reason, they have demonstrated that they are likely to make bad decisions in the future, even if this particular time things turned out well. Thus, it is in society's interest to castigate the person doing something for a bad reason even if the result was good.

When someone does something good for a bad reason, the long-term result is more harm, both in the possible future bad choices of the person and anyone who might emulate that person. Intentions matter, but only because it affects long-term consequences.

I see ethics and our sense of morality as just a part of evolutionary traits. I came to this idea because I believe in moral antirealism that is there is not moral facts or truth that it's all in our head.
The reason I see the sense of morality as just a part of evolutionary traits is because it varies widely among groups of people and circumstances. I see this as an adaptation to an environment. The reason most of us don't condemn the Donna party for cannibalism is because that was necessary for the survival of the group. In this way, ethics is just a part of social norms and conventions to maximize the survival and success of a group of species like a colony of honeybees or ants. Even these organisms have some social rules to guide their behavior that maximizes the survival of the group. But most likely the rules differ depending on the environment and the character of the group much like the social rules of us humans. I speculate that we developed our sense of morality because the harmonious and collaborative group was more successful in its survival. It's completely arbitrary construct but is absolutely necessary for social animals. We know this is true when we imagine a human being lone in a spaceship living by himself for his entire life because ethics become irrelevant.

Lest anyone be confused, moral relativism in the descriptive, as opposed to normative, sense is NOT a metaethical theory. Since it's simply a statement about how beliefs differ from culture to culture, it makes no statement one way or another about the status of moral facts (whether they exist or not) and so is neither a form of moral realism or anti-realism on it's own. It is an important thing to discuss here since many people get descriptive moral relativism confused with normative moral relativism (which IS a metaethical theory) and/or use descriptive moral relativism as a justification for some other moral antirealist position. When I was 16 I had a great fascination with ancient reptiles and studied paleontology nonstop. I developed a great deal of respect for the dinosaurs given as they dominated the world for hundreds of millions of years ( whereas humans had only for a couple thousand ) and that they were so successful in adapting and evolving to countless conditions around the world. I sometimes thought that if dinosaurs had taken their success one step further and developed their own complex civilizations what their ethics would be. I asked myself if even basic moral rules would apply to animals other than humans. Like would murder be wrong for these civilized dinos? Or is that just a rule that applies exclusively to some part of the primate, human, brain that these animals wouldn't have. I thought about these a lot and studied biology, philosophy, psychology, and other sciences in search of an answer. I eventually figured stuff out but I still find it funny to think about how much sleep I lost asking myself if civilized birds would be cool with manslaughter.

Objective moral facts exist --- And here is why:

Objective moral facts = That which is discovered to be good/right and non-good/non-right independent of the beliefs and opinions of non-rational people. Those people who discover objective moral facts and think and act in accordance to them are called rational people.

P1. Rational people experience that objective moral facts exist.
*Nature: Rational people experience that there are objectively good/right and non-good/non-right natural desires and urges.
*Nurture: Rational people experience that there are objectively good/right and non-good/non-right upbringing and conditioning.
*Opinions and beliefs: Rational people experience that there are objectively good/right and non-good/non-right opinions and beliefs.
*Actions and behaviour: Rational people experience that there are objectively good/right and non-good/non-right actions and behaviour.

P2. Rational people experience that objective moral facts are "as real as" bodies, cars, the experience of pain and the taste of coffee.

P3. There is no evidence demonstrating that the experience that objective moral facts exist is non-true.

P4. The claim by materialism/naturalism -- that the objective moral facts rational people experience are non-existent (aka illusory) -- is a non-rational claim.
*Materialism/naturalism do not know what space and time is ... what matter is ... what mind and consciousness is ... what experience is ... what life is ... what a human being is ... and yet they claim to be in a position to know that objective moral facts do not exist. This is a non-sensible, non-reasonable and non-logical claim.

C: Objective moral facts exist.

I don't think that learning to be "good" (in whatever sense that any particular culture might define good) is the point of moral philosophy. Like most else that has guided human evolution, or much else that humans do, moral philosophy is a memetic tool for survival. Being "good" isn't even secondary, but tertiary.

In any proper moral system, the survival of the practitioners' group always has the highest value. Next comes truth, which has a value that overrides everything other than survival. After that come values such as justice, freedom, etc.

Justice has a value inferior to truth. That's because the pursuit of justice depends on knowing truth, or more exactly on the ability accurately to distinguish truth from falsehood.

And likewise for freedom. Without a means by which the truth can be identified after all its imposters have been found and discarded, you can't even tell whether you really are free, let alone pursue freedom with any confidence.

Notice also that the only value higher than truth is survival. Nothing matters to the dead — not even truth. Only to something alive may anything else be good (or have value). A rock doesn't care whether you hit it with a hammer. But a mouse does.

Why the group, and not the individual? Because individuals are ephemeral. We can by no means endure as the ages pass. But the group of practitioners, having a moral system in common, which they heed and advance in the world, can indeed endure. And the most natural group is a race, which is strongest when its members hold a moral system in common; i.e. isn't factionalized, and therefore cannot be induced to attack itself.

When the group of practitioners is also a race, it gains the ability to replace its dying members with new members who are born compatible with the culture of their fellows. Because inherited are most of the human qualities that determine which memetic qualities the individual can easily acquire, or can acquire at all. Native members have the requisite temperament and innate attributes for engaging in the group's culture; they're organic, not grafted in. They belong without having to adapt, as an outsider would have to adapt though continuous exertion. (And the immigrant will in most cases be unwilling to put forth the required effort.)

What doesn't exist is worthless. What can't exist for long because of self-sabotage isn't worth much. Proper moral codes, which put the survival of the practitioners' group first in value, are therefore always better than improper moral codes, which give the highest value to anything else. A group that puts the highest moral value on anything other than survival will, sooner or later, encounter circumstances in which their survival is in conflict with whatever that other thing is. When that happens, the group will either abandon their improper moral system in favor of a proper one, or they will die off, and their improper code will vanish along with them.

I won't declare the foregoing summary of moral philosophy to be the final word in moral philosophy. I'm not that pretentious. But it appears to be self-consistent and consistent with how the world really works. If anyone discovers a flaw, I'd like to hear about it.

I think that one of the ways in which one culture can make war on another is by inducing its rival, by propaganda or by some other means, to get their moral priorities improperly sorted. Has this already happened; i.e., is such a war going on now? I suspect so, but I'll save the details for some other time.

I'd argue that morality is an evolutionary trait that can be parted in two categories: primal and abstract.

There is primal morality such as letting women and children off boats first, and intuitivly knowing that harming children is wrong. this type of morality would correspond to the reptilian mind, something that is outside our controll and fundamental to the species survival.

Then there is the abstract morality which would correspond to epigenetic effects. If there are moral facts, then they exist independent of our beliefs. Else two moral agents who disagree will be equally right.
We need free will to be moral agents, as any cause of action that was not free, is merely part of the action initiated by the most recent necessary(cause) free moral agent.

Moral progress actually takes on an entirely different meaning from relativism: Something can progress toward a goal given one moral paradigm, while "regressing" according to a different paradigm. What I arbitrarily say is progress, others would say it's regression. Popularity of an idea is what causes it to be upheld as "moral" in most cases, and cultural relativists should recognize that wrong acts are "right" in the context of another culture's paradigms, but anyone with a preference has the right to hold the opinion that a cultural moral "rule" is regressive; according to their own internal views on morality, it IS regressive and there's no real reason not to call it out if it is your wont to do so.

I wonder if Hank will talk about moral calculus. One of the metaethical questions asked earlier in this episode was "Is it right to steal in order to feed your family?". Moral calculus gets an input of objective positive and negative consequences regarding a certain ethical decision and outputs the decision that should be made. So back to that question. Let's say you have 2 children, you are very poor, and your children are starving. You then see a pie that was put to cool on a open window that was left by the baker. You overhear from the baker that a wealthy individual will come by later to pick up and buy this pie. Let's look at the positives and negatives if you steal the pie.
+You and your children can keep living and won't die from starvation
+This wealthy individual can buy another pie quite easily with no financial concerns
-The baker loses time and money spent making the pie
-The baker has to spend time and money to make another one
-Wealthy individual must wait more time to buy the pie
When weighing these pros and cons against each other, we can see that the baker and individual losing some cash and time weighs far less than children dying. There are still many different variable to consider. Would it be more ethical to ask the baker if he can give you the pie for your starving children? What if the baker is also extremely poor? I'm not saying this is the absolute solution to the problems and questions philosophers ask regarding metaethics but it is very interesting.

To state something is right or wrong assumes someone knows which is which, wich in turn then assumes that there is such a thing as right and wrong. We get stuck here not because it is hard to figure out what this objective morality is, or that only a few of us have figured it out, but rather because we get lost in semantics. We confuse a concept which is put into place to preserve the rules and structures of a society, or a ruler (right and wrong), to be objective truth. It is because we fail to question the prime assumtion, being our use of language, that we fail to answer these questions. The words "right" and "wrong" are constructs of hierarchy and authority (societal constructs) and have nothing to do with our subjective experience of the world. We may have strong opinions and/or emotional responses relating to certain things but this will only give us an understanding of ourselves and will give us no information about an assumed objective morality.

Cultural relativism and moral relativism should be in the category of moral anti-realism. That is due to the three's similar belief that moral facts are subjective due to conditions of opinions, cultural norms and/or attitudes.

A slightly more nuanced realist theory than absolutism is that, instead of some things being wrong always without question, there are certain things that are "prima facie" wrong, which means that an action being that thing "counts against" that action, although there can be balancing factors that make the act okay. So, to take an example from Michael Huemer: killing cats is prima facie wrong. So, an action being an instance of cat-killing counts against that action. However, if the cat has a deadly disease that can only be gotten rid of by burning it, that can override the wrongness and make it okay to kill the cat, although the action is still wrong to some extent, insofar as it is an instance of cat-killing. Also, disagreement isn't a good argument against moral realism. Consider science. Yeah, right now there are a lot of issues where there is consensus in the scientific community. However, there are also many issues where there's hot disagreement, and if we look to the past, almost every scientific issue was hotly debated at one point pr another. So it seems like a domain's being objective doesn't preclude there being disagreement in that domain, and I don't see why morality should be any exception. There doesn't even have to be a way to know what the truth is; to steal another example from Huemer, consider the case of the JFK assassination. Nobody knows, or even could know, what happened that day, but nobody disputes that there is some fact of the matter about what did happen. Also, side note, I'm not really all that clear on how the burglar example was relevant. It's a really interesting example, but I wasn't sure how it tied in to this video specifically.

I'll be interested to learn more about the ethical theories from a more trustworthy source (I've mostly gotten taught about them from a political science student whose politics I disagree with and wikipedia). Right now, I suspect my personal view on ethics would be seen as a (possibly lazy) side-stepping of the problems with utilitarian ethics if I tried presenting it to academics. I think the greatest society is the one that creates the greatest chance of happiness among its specific subset of people, by removing as many obstacles to their personal path as is practical. That method is particularly important because I disagree with the concept of measuring people's happiness as "pain" and "pleasure". I think the measurement for ethical utility should remain a vague and mushy grey-ness because even trying to average out the extreme differences people within the same sub-culture can have would make no one happy. I agree partially with the idea that there's morals that can be considered "objective," but only in the sense that they're more practical to a herd of living beings (ie. murder is wrong because it takes away members of the herd that could've been useful further down the line, causes lower productivity and fulfillment for the loved ones of the victim, and lowers trust among the herd due to the increased normality of inter-herd killing). However, I think there's a very harsh limit on how much wisdom can be gained from strictly objective morality, with the rest having to be glossed from the situation and the people involved.

I think a few things are morally absolute, but only those few. I consider these things to be absolutely wrong: unjustified killing of other members of your species, causing unjustified pain to another member of your species, and causing unjustified psychological damage to another member of your species. Wrongheaded intent, whether it successfully manifests itself as wrongdoing or not, should be corrected if present. Well-meaning intent, whether it successfully manifests itself as a positive out come or not, should be commended if present.

I like to distinguish between morality and ethics. Morality is the intent to achieve good, for others as well as for yourself. The goal of morality is the best possible good and least possible harm for everyone. Ethics are rules, and rules are one of the tools we use to improve good and reduce harm for everyone. The distinction between morality and ethics is important, because morality is the meta-ethics of ethics. The rules serve moral intent. And we judge between two rules by how well they achieve good and reduce harm. For example, our laws once supported slavery and protected the slave master's ownership by requiring that runaway slaves be returned to their owners. However, we replaced these laws with new laws that outlawed slavery and later outlawed racial discrimination. Why did we make this change? Because it eliminated the harm being done through servitude and opened up participation in our economy and democracy to everyone. So morality is the meta-ethic of ethics.

Dear Hank,
I'm sorry but I have to object to your account of "fundamental assumptions" regarding Theory of Natural Law and Utilitarianism.
1) Although the theory of natural law is sometimes understood as a normative theory; it's better understood as a metaethical theory (roughly "natural" means "good" and "unnatural" means "bad" - See James Rachels' Elements of Moral Philosophy for a full account).
2) Utilitarianism doesn't assume that all beings share a desire for pleasure (although it does assume happiness, or utility, is inherently valuable). If there exists an X such that X does not seek pleasure or avoid pain, the utilitarian still has to care about that being's well-being. Furthermore, there are many "beings" that don't seek pleasure - AKA, those without the capacity to feel pleasure. Perhaps you mean "agent" here, but utilitarianism only seeks to maximize happiness - not maximize agent's happiness.

Otherwise, this was a fun video. Keep up the good work.

Relativism is not a form of realism, in either of the senses of realism, which you didn't bother to distinguish. "Robust" realism insists that moral propositions assert mind-independent facts about the world, some of which are true; relativism, being dependent on the minds of people, is thus not robustly realist. "Minimal" realism only insists that moral propositions, whatever it is they do, are objectively right or wrong; that is the exact opposite of relativism. Absolutism is an orthogonal issue entirely, the opposite of which is consequentialism or contextualism, either of which can be realist (in either sense) or relativist.
